content.line: It is a custom in some parts of Africa for travelers into the jungles to send before them in the early morning little African boys called “Dew-driers” to brush with their bodies the dew from the high grasses—and be, perchance, the first to meet the leopard’s or hyena’s challenge—and so open the road. “Human Brooms,” Dan Crawford calls them.
For as the firefly lights the night

line.figLang: Bathed in the dank dews as he goes forth
Behold a little black boy, a naked black boy,

content.line: Sweeping aside with his slight frame
And making a morning path to the light
Bathed in the blood of battle
May not his race—its body long bared to the world’s disdain,
Its face schooled to smile for a light to come—
May not his race, even as the dew-boy leads,

line.figLang: Bear onward the world toward a new day-dawn

content.line: Such as reigned in the heart of One
Shall shape the earth for that fresh dawning
